description.narrative: -- This/these answers have been migrated from a previous version of Trac -- The SAfAIDS SCORE intervention's overall aim to contribute to a sustained 50% reduction in new infections and improved positive sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) outcomes for communities in southern Africa by 2018.

SAfAIDS har ansökt om 40 000 000 SEK i bidrag till genomförandet av det 5-åriga programmet ”Sustainable Communities of Real Excellence (SCORE)” i södra Afrika (Lesotho, Malawi, Sydafrika, Swaziland, Zambia och Zimbabwe) under perioden 2014-2018. Syftet är att fram till 2018 bidra till en halvering av nya HIV- infektioner samt förbättrad sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter (SRHR) i samhällen i södra Afrika. Det svenska bidraget föreslås att vara i form av kärnstöd och kommer finansiera verksamhet inom programmet under perioden 1 juli 2014 - 30 juni 2017.
Projektförslaget innehåller tre strategiska mål: 1. Motverka hiv, tuberkulos och könsrelaterat våld samt främja tillgång SRHR bland unga mellan 10-24 år i södra Afrika. 2. Öka tillgången till tjänster som hanterar SRH, hiv, tuberkulos och könsrelaterat våld för marginaliserade kvinnor mellan 25-49 år i södra Afrika 3. Främja diskriminerade gruppers (hbt-personer, personer som lever med hiv, sexarbetare och fångar) mänskliga rättigheter i syfte att förebygga hiv, tuberkulos, könsrelaterat våld och homofobi genom att förbättra tillgången till icke-stigmatiserande SRHR information och service.

SAfAIDS has applied to Sida for funding of 40 000 000 SEK to carry out the five year program "Sustainable Communities of Real Excellence" (SCORE) in southern Africa (Lesotho, Malawi, South Africa, Swaziland, Zambia and Zimbabwe) during the period 2014-2018. The Swedish contribution is proposed to be core support and cover activities during the period from July 1, 2014 until June 30, 2017.
The intervention aims at contributing to a sustained 50% reduction in new infections and improved positive sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) outcomes for communities in southern Africa by 2018. The program has three core strategic objectives: 1. Promote access to strategic, evidence-based HIV, TB, SGBV prevention and SRH&R information and services that enhance preventative behaviors and demand for SRH services by young people aged 10-24 years (in and out of schools, in prisons and informal settlements surrounding mines) in Southern Africa by 2018. 2. Scale up SRH&R interventions that promote prevention of HIV, TB and SGBV and enhance referrals and uptake of key SRH services for vulnerable women 25-49 years (in prisons and informal settlements surrounding mines) in Southern Africa by 2018. 3. Promote the rights of key populations (LGBTI, people living with HIV (PLHIV), prisoners and sex workers) to prevent HIV, TB, SGBV, and homophobia to enhance access to non stigmatized SRHR information and services

participating-org.narrative: SAFAIDS/Southern Africa Hiv & Aids Information Dissemination Services

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Sida has collaborated with SAfAIDS since 2004. SAfAIDS works to address gender equality and the rights of women, girls and key population groups, to access sexual reproductive health services and rights by confronting issues like harmful traditions, culture, and stigma. SAfAIDS and its implementing partners have implemented the SCORE Programme (July 2014-December 2017). The programme which aimed to contribute to a sustained 50% reduction in new HIV infections and improved positive SRH outcomes for communities in southern Africa, was implemented in six countries; eSwatini, Lesotho, Malawi, South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe. The following results have been achieved: Objective 1: Promote access to strategic, evidence-informed HIV, TB, SGBV prevention and SRH&R information and services that promote preventive behaviors and demand for SRH services by young people aged 10-24 years (in and out of schools, in prisons, informal settlements surrounding mines) in southern Africa by 2018. Focus was on reaching out to young people (YP) through intergenerational dialogues, high volume music bashes and galas, one-on-one dialogues, Hop on Mobile Taxi dialogues, radio listening and reading clubs, social media, TV and radio programmes. A total of 118,435 (F64,499; M53,936) YP were reached with HIV, TB and SGBV information while 28,556 YP aged 10-25 years were referred for SRH services with 19,516 (F10,958; M8,558) accessing SRH and SGBV services. The YPLA trained 24 (F15; 9M) mentees (out of school) and 14 (F9, 5M) in-school adolescents under the Holiday Leadership Class. Key Results: According to the sentinel site survey conducted in 2016, YP who participated in SAfAIDS activities demonstrated more knowledge on HIV compared to their counterparts who never participated. In Zimbabwe, 77% of YP who participated vs 55% who did not participate were able to identify at least 3 correct HIV prevention methods. A similar trend was noted in Zambia (68% vs 55%), South Africa (63% vs 16%) and eSwatini (73% vs 48%). On comprehensive knowledge on SRHR, YP exposed to SAfAIDS activities were more knowledgeable than their counterparts who never participated: (South Africa - 49% vs 3%; eSwatini – 42% vs 2%; Zambia – 66% vs 39% and Zimbabwe – 36% vs 26%). On uptake of services, the survey revealed that HIV testing in the past 12 months was higher among YP exposed to SAfAIDS activities: South Africa - 79% vs 39%; Zambia - 55% vs 43%; and Zimbabwe - 68% vs 54%. Objective 2: Scale up SRHR interventions that promote prevention of HIV, TB and SGBV and enhance referrals and uptake of key services for vulnerable women 25-49 years and young people in prisons and informal settlements around mines in southern Africa by 2018. Activities implemented included "Men as Protectors" (MasP) and "Women as Partners" trainings, community dialogues, community women’s health days and Women’s Social Network Dialogues on HIV, TB and GBV Prevention and SRH Promotion. 46 MasP clubs were established in Lesotho (25) and Malawi (21) with MasP activities reaching out to 30,650 men and 44,078 women in Lesotho, Malawi and Zimbabwe with SRHR, HIV prevention and GBV information. 9,698 were referred for SRH and GBV services while 5,600 women accessed SRH, HIV prevention and GBV services. Key Results: The programme increased knowledge on HIV and SRHR among adults. More adults exposed to SAfAIDS activities had comprehensive HIV transmission knowledge (64%) compared to 50% among adults who were never exposed. The programme contributed to increased uptake of HIV, TB, GBV prevention and SRH services by women in marginalized settings (prisons, informal settlements around mines). In communities where MasPs were formed, the programme significantly contributed to meaningful participation of men and traditional leaders in prevention of HIV and GBV against women. Objective 3: Promote the rights of key populations to address human rights issues of key populations (LGBTI, prisoners and sex workers) to prevent HIV, TB, GBV, and homophobia and enhance access to non-stigmatized SRH & Rights information and services Activities undertaken include regional and national KP dialogues, establishment of Sex Workers Action Groups (SWAGs), national and regional KP taskforces. 84 leaders participated in regional policy dialogues on HIV prevention for prisoners, LGBTI and people who sell sex. 12 SWAGs were established and supported in South Africa and Zimbabwe. 678 people who sell sex were reached with information on HIV and GBV prevention. Key Results: There was increased perception of risk among LGBTI and sex workers and increased uptake of HIV, SGBV prevention and SRH services by LGBTI and people who sell sex. Political, religious and traditional leaders supported KPs through action and advocacy for equal access to SRH services. KP advocacy dialogues influenced policy formulation and reviews on LGBTI rights and rights of people who sell sex.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
